title: U.K. House Prices Flatline in September
text:
U.K. house prices flatlined in September, with the average home gaining only 0.2% in value compared to the same time last year, according to the latest Nationwide House Price Index on Tuesday.



Home values have now been rising at anemic rates under 1% for 10 straight months, as political wrangling over Brexit intensified. September also marked the last month of the third quarter, when home prices rose by 0.3%, the slowest growth since 2013, according to Nationwide, the longest-running index in the U.K.

“Indicators of U.K. economic activity have been fairly volatile in recent quarters, but the underlying pace of growth appears to have slowed as a result of weaker global growth and an intensification of Brexit uncertainty,” wrote Robert Gardner, Nationwide’s chief economist, in the report.



Homeowners in the British capital and its outer commuter ring have suffered the most from the ongoing downturn. In London, home values fell 1.7% in the third quarter compared to a year ago, while the outer metro area saw prices decline 1.5% during the same period, according to Halifax’s seasonally adjusted figures.



This is the ninth month in a row that London home prices declined year-over-year, though they are still only 5% below their all-time high in Q1 2017, according to the index. The average home price in London is also still 50% higher than it was in 2007.

If there’s any bright spot for the market, it’s that recent mortgage approval data shows that total home sales across the country have remained broadly stable, Mr. Gardner wrote.



“Healthy labor market conditions and low borrowing costs appear to be offsetting the drag from the uncertain economic outlook,” he added.
